22:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["Living in ","Puerto Madero"]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed","children":[["$","p","0",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Puerto Madero is what happens when you redevelop an entire port district into a luxury residential and commercial zone. The neighborhood's modern glass towers, manicured waterfront promenade, and upscale restaurants make it feel more like Miami or Dubai than Buenos Aires. It's the safest neighborhood in the city — private security is everywhere, streets are immaculate, and the overall atmosphere is controlled and predictable. For certain expats, this is exactly what they want: a modern, safe, comfortable base with gyms, pools, and concierge services built into every tower","."]}],["$","p","1",{"className":"mb-4","children":["The Ecological Reserve (Reserva Ecológica) at the waterfront is a surprising oasis of nature, popular for running and cycling. The dining along the docks is upscale and scenic. The main criticism is that Puerto Madero doesn't feel like Buenos Aires — or even like Argentina. It's a sterile, purpose-built neighborhood that lacks the character, history, and street life that make BA special","."]}],["$","p","2",{"className":"mb-4","children":["On weekends, when the office workers are gone, it can feel empty. The rents are the highest in the city, and you're paying for safety and modernity rather than culture or community.",""]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"mt-12","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm
